Key Arguments: The bill undermines freedom of speech by creating an unjust power dynamic between citizens and authorities.
The legislation poses a risk to democratic expression by imposing excessive fines and restrictions on digital services.
Determining truth is complex and evolving, and the bill may mistakenly censor evolving information.
The bill targets not only false information but also potentially misleading or deceptive information, infringing on free speech.
The legislation could have unintended consequences for smaller community websites and international platforms.
The bill may suppress minority voices that challenge established beliefs and drive progress.
Delegating legislative power to private entities raises constitutional concerns and bypasses parliamentary oversight.
The bill assumes government and authorized entities possess ultimate truth, undermining democratic inclusion and diversity.
The provisions threaten digital platforms and users with reputational damage and financial penalties, resembling totalitarian systems.
Independent media, journalists, and bloggers face complex reporting standards that favor government-approved publications.
Notable Quotes: The Internet, being the most powerful democratic invention of humanity, has empowered regular people by giving them a voice.
This bill, which claims to protect minorities, may, in fact, suppress them.
The delegation of legislative power to private entities under this bill raises significant constitutional concerns.
